column5: Another brilliant @cyberlyra opt-out experiment: how to escape Disneyland’s surveillance apparatus. Hint: paint your kids’ faces, give them fake names, and struggle to get food. https://t.co/VDhvQx8Rl4

CfP: "The Politics of Data and Quantification in the Public Sector" <-- @Liu_Chuncheng and I are hosting a session at @ASAnews as part of the SKAT section. Submit your paper by 2/22! Deets: https://t.co/C4hDZG0E84
Anyone have recommendations on how to find a homestay near Hội An? We’d love to stay with a family in a cultural exchange esque context.

Bullying is psychological, physical, or social meanness and cruelty, repeated over time, exacted by someone who holds differential power. 

Bystanders watch. Downstanders enable. WTF kind of culture are we modeling? 

"What we do in life echoes through eternity."

@bgneumeyer Individual profiles. Including musicians, some quasi-celebrities like Paris Hilton, some "fake" accounts that were funny, what we would now call "creators" or "influencers", etc. Much of it was joy-inducing, some drama-filled, far less just sheer anger generating.

Is Twitter failing? What does failure look like? Right now, it's an absurdist spectacle made for Rome. Here are some reflections on past social media/org failures and what they might teach us about the current situation: https://t.co/zExYbownni https://t.co/dXac0AQ7Ro

@brandonsilverm @STS_News Indeed they are cuz their subscription model doesn’t enable a hockey stick. But they’ll burn thru that too. Cuz profitability is not enough. Hockey sticks invite creepier and creepier practices. Only thing that grows like that in nature is called cancer. And it kills the host.

@STS_News The profitability of surveillance depends on being able to sell that data. To anyone from advertisers to goons. Surveillance as guaranteed pathway to wealth is deterministic logic, oblivious to structural configurations. But determinisms are soooo ripe for frothiness.

@STS_News Because “surveillance capitalism” is so amorphous in that book, I’m not sure which variant you’re thinking of. For me, the story of Alexa is more a story of when/where ads and subscriptions are a viable business plan in a financialized ROI framework.

Wow - @MauriceWFP's reflections on how to build resilient orgs are phenomenal (as are his examinations of what makes progressive orgs a mess). For advocates and those working in civil society, I cannot recommend this essay enough: https://t.co/fcVWYFi6vD

Reminder: Microsoft Research sociotechnical internship apps due 12/2! (Postdoc apps due a week later!) These are great opportunities for advanced PhD students in the social sciences! https://t.co/JHTLsF3agS
https://t.co/vLjgE4VuxX

PhD students: Want to work with @marylgray @nancybaym @TarletonG and me at @MSFTResearch on sociotechnical projects? We are hiring both interns and postdocs. For more info, see: https://t.co/XqOy6mm2TR
@kashif_imteyaz @nancybaym @TarletonG @marylgray This means “advanced to candidacy.” In most places, this involves completing coursework, qualifying exams, and having proposed a dissertation project.
@KLdivergence Omg enjoy the rabbit hole of Dunbar’s number! You’ll feel Ike you’ve truly timewarped to 2003! That was the cap on Friendster at one point!!
@Thoreaus_Horse Cats are the key to all happiness.
@KLdivergence ::laugh:: Long live Robin Dunbar. Do you think he’s watching and groaning?
@DataGeekB Aren’t they all? Aren’t we all?
The other much more serious question: will there be kittens on mastadon? Most of my social media activity has devolved into watching kitten videos…. Hmm….

I’m so curious who all plans to shift to mastadon on Friday. I realized I haven’t built a new social media network in a loooooong time. I’m pondering what it would be like to start again. Fun? Hell? I can’t decide.

D&S is the product of many people's contributions. Team members who built the website, created financial systems, found temporary offices, convened events, and ran full-speed to publish explainers. I can't thank y'all enough. Thank you. May the next 10 years be equally magical.

A few weeks back, I announced that I'm going to step off of the @datasociety board at the 10-year mark. I've been laughing, crying, and reminiscing over these kind words from some of the people who helped make D&S possible in that first year. https://t.co/Y2oPBoeCf2
This fantastic new report  makes you grapple with the tensions between "security" and surveillance (not to mention worker management) that are literally at your doorstep.

So in this moment of transition, let me offer a huge {{HUG}} to everyone who has helped make @datasociety possible in countless ways big and small over the years. A founder should only be one part of an org's story. Personally, I can't wait to read the next chapter! <grin>

I'm also confident that @datasociety is in good hands. The brilliant @cmcilwain has graciously agreed to become the next board chair. And the amazing @janethaven will continue to serve as ED. And there are just so many other incredible people at the org.

This is not really goodbye, but a shift. I love @datasociety dearly. In March, I will become an advisor, happy to help when I can. And I will re-engage as a researcher. And I will also always be a cheerleader for all of the amazing and impactful work that folks do!

Personal update: I've decided to step down from @datasociety's board in March 2023, 10 years from when I first envisioned the org. I will shift into an advisory role. Here's a toast to the next phase! https://t.co/MjRuUaQuRh
Omg the NYT review of @danbouk’s book about the census by @AlexandraJacobs is as endearingly nerdy as the book itself. https://t.co/JOUlM1k2Zs

20 years ago, I was declared a terrorist by Yahoo! & lost all of my content on that platform (cuz I was working with Afghani feminists). That radically changed how I approached the internet. Today, another story about why context matters in content mod: https://t.co/i8B8K2Zdek

My mother said it best when she remarked that my grandpa took his last flight today. He was 100 and he lived a surreal life. He was the ghost worker behind early airline navigation algorithms, although his WWII survival story is better documented: https://t.co/8DaVVMQtLX
@geomblog Thank you for your service. Now, for the most important question: what are you going to do with all of those snazzy suits you acquired?

I'm going to be at #asa22 this weekend. Haven't done a big conference in years. Curious if I will be able to recognize anyone in masks. (If you see me, come say hi! I have a full undercut & a blue backpack these days.)

@gregmepstein @sivavaid @steveglista @page88 @nicole_ellison @m_c_elish I'd argue it's not that simple. MZ needs engineers, users, Wall Street. He has significant power but not total control. (I'm implicitly invoking SCOT. Are you familiar with this lineage of thinking? Classic place to start: https://t.co/Ovgle5W1W3 )

@sivavaid @steveglista @gregmepstein @page88 @nicole_ellison There were many teens who leveraged an opening circa 2004-2006 to create different trajectories for themselves, ones rooted in potential. AND there were horror stories. These are not contradictory. Diff peoples’ truths. What I see now is a narrower range of possibility.

@sivavaid @steveglista @gregmepstein @page88 @nicole_ellison I often worry that the techlash is just as deterministic as Silicon Valley’s thinking. Yes, the config of $$/power narrows the range of possible futures but it doesn’t pre-ordain them. The experiences people have with SM/SNS are not universal. Good, bad, AND ugly.

@sivavaid @steveglista @gregmepstein @page88 @nicole_ellison I guess the problem I have with this framing is that no technology was ever just about its founders. They were all co-constructed by teens and VCs and engineers and all sorts of other folks with competing visions, complex power matrices. Including FB.

@amcunningham @mlaundy I do. And I will be taking one in January/February. The key is not just to turn off your email, but to actively and intentionally communicate with all who are impacted by your break. To responsibly create closure. Like you might with parental leave.

@jeffjarvis @nicole_ellison @JeremyLittau @sivavaid @Klonick I get the sense of a serious decline. Folks "see" the loud/vocal speakers in their networks (sometimes). There are still some sub-communities actually talking on Twitter but that appears to have weakened. (But I'm not collecting current data so take with a grain of salt.)

@nicole_ellison @JeremyLittau @jeffjarvis @sivavaid @Klonick Even what we once called SM or SNS have shifted to amplifying entertainment for $$. You can find connections in the interstices. But most people don't even try. And they're getting drowned by algos. At best, they've reverted to closed groups to connect.

@nicole_ellison @JeremyLittau @jeffjarvis @sivavaid @Klonick Personally, I think social media is dead. At least as I originally understood it. SNSs were about articulating relationships, not fandom. Social media was about enabling sociality not parasociality. We have a new genre of entertainment, of celebrity. But it ain't social media.
Scholarly friends: What are your favorite kinds of methods chapters in ethnographies? What do you wish all ethnographers would detail about their work? (Favorite examples?)
I forgot to share this conversation I did with the grad student podcast team at @Georgetown. If you're interested in data and truth, you might enjoy it. <grin> https://t.co/vVM4trCf1u

@JoeBeOne @davekarpf For me, probably 2002-2008. I feel like it came of age after the dot com crash and survived until F8, which I mark as total Facebook takeover. (LJ, Xanga, etc were earlier but they aren’t core blogosphere for me. And people were blogging before but the community aspect came then)

Every time I learn of a YA book being banned, I buy it. Stunned by what scares people. Also can’t help but notice how many are graphic novels. Are the censors even reading or just panicking about cartoon people who don’t look like them?
Another amazing zinger from @danbouk: "Democracy Is Asking Too Much of Its Data." Congress has more power in how it uses census data than people realize. https://t.co/kTbTTIOdIU

I'm hiring freelance RAs w/ expertise in STS or OrgSoc or PubAdmin or HistStats to be the Reviewer #2 that we all dream of. Ideal for post-quals PhD students or others w/ similar experience. Full job description here: https://t.co/xJ2h7OWcOp
Privacy folks: this one is for you!
For all who are obsessing over Maloney v. Nadler in NYC redistricting, just know that it didn't have to be this way. @danbouk offers some history to put this into context: https://t.co/CFXe4JyMOT
While I’ve written some entertaining out-of-office messages over the years, Iceland’s tourism unit has a better idea: https://t.co/mfAnswcdjm
@twinsmomma3 @latimes In case it helps: https://t.co/zXcjfF6re9

My friend @cyberlyra tried really really really hard to hide her pregnancy from data trackers. It was an insane journey. So anyone who thinks that the key to fertility privacy is to "opt out" should read what she has to say: https://t.co/aPYAt8yexf
Read the thread. They did such an amazing job of teasing out “radicalization” across lits from a range of fields. Such important work.

Trying hard not to lose my mind that Congress/SCOTUS care more about the Court's right to privacy and control of decisions than the privacy/control/rights of pregnant people. Oh, the excruciating irony.
Wow. What an amazing article about @AlondraNelson46's contributions to OSTP. (STS sociologists rock!!) Tx @nancyscola! https://t.co/2FF0gOO44u
"What You Don’t Know About Amazon" by @moiragweigel does a phenomenal job of unpacking the systemic risk produced by our current supply chain arrangement. https://t.co/nh7BX812jT

"Differential Perspectives: Epistemic Disconnects Surrounding the US Census Bureau’s Use of Differential Privacy" tries to unpack how statistical illusions got upended by exposing the limitations of census data, calling into question statistical imaginaries that surround census.
Attempting to make sense of the controversy around census and differential privacy, @jksarathy and I penned an essay based on our fieldwork: https://t.co/NWzAtJRx5G
Congrats @janethaven and others selected to this important committee!

The reading list is intended primarily for scholars building syllabi and for students looking to contextualize data science. But the commentary might be of interest to all (and it's short!). Key arguments below. https://t.co/YZXXUSNRAl

"A Primer on Powerful Numbers" is an annotated reading list/quasi-syllabus/commentary for those interested in official statistics and the politics of numbers. By @danbouk @Keviriah and me. https://t.co/8hASKqAsAO

"The Datafied State" is a new @datasociety research initiative led by @jennaburrell and Ranjit Singh. Learn more: https://t.co/OjlbamQf72  (PS: I'm no longer directly involved in D&S initiatives but am still super excited by them!)
@lizthegrey @CrisisTextLine My mistake. (Reposted.)
While this change is important and necessary, there are many unresolved questions about how to ethically serve people in crisis. These are top of mind for me right now. (3/3) https://t.co/LEjjMyTwKu
A little while ago, @CrisisTextLine also announced that we ended our data-sharing agreement with Loris: https://t.co/WBNTedlCTG I was wrong when I agreed to this relationship. (2/3)

I am on the board of @CrisisTextLine. Many people are asking us to account for our decisions. To do so, I wrote a blog post detailing my ongoing struggle to govern responsibly and ethically: https://t.co/SMoRFeVrmX (1/3)
Oh how I needed this satire right now.
@JuliaTicona1 My littlest is almost 5. She still talks about aminals with joy. And my 7yo will revert to blutterflies to make us all smile. Oh how I love those pronunciation joys.
This op-ed nailed the school/covid/funding/values cultural chaos ball: https://t.co/GIFB2F4r4p

CFP: The @TheCLAlliance is thinking about "human experience." They have an interesting CFP for folks who think about youth, well being, design, learning, tech governance, etc. See: https://t.co/yCNAB1IxlQ
The team @ReligPublicLife have been doing a deep dive on what #interfaith / religious diversity online looks like. Enjoy:  https://t.co/KJDzZR5mfN

@robyncaplan Oof. It's hard to believe that it's been 25 years since I first tried to understand this. Weird to re-read this provocation given how much more we know now about biases in system design. https://t.co/jEvyU2ecC5
This. (Cuz normally I just grunt. Or scream. Or shake my fists.)

Some days, the butterfly effect is visible. Sat down to read a 1998 book by a scholar I admire but don’t know. Phone buzzes. Email from said scholar. “We don’t know each other but…” ::shaking head:: Love to the knots in the universe.
@fxshaw @neilhimself “The Graveyard Book.” Last session was “Other Words for Home” by @jasminewarga and “Inside Out and Back Again” by @ThanhhaLai if you want more yummy middle grade.

I’ve always found that the books I read shape how I write. Hence, I’ve long re-read various books/chapters before a writing session. Now, thanks to my kids, I’m on a heavy diet of middle grade books. What will that do to my writing? (This week is being shaped by @neilhimself )
Is water justice your thing? (Nom nom geeky infrastructure.) Check out this new report on Water Justice & Tech, edited by @theodorajewell : https://t.co/HTdFaiUReE

New @datasociety report by @ystvns & @_Ryan_Ellis explores the history and present of bug bounty programs with an eye towards labor precarity in security. Tis a fascinating read: https://t.co/6HdPxh1150

I'm super excited that Ellen Pao and Raina Kumra are joining the Data & Society board! (Anil Dash has termed out. And Alex Macgillivray has joined the federal govt. Saaad on those fronts but stoked on our amazing new additions!)

Academics: Georgetown has 3 "digital ethics" job openings: 
1. McDevitt Chair for Center for Digital Ethics: https://t.co/7j5UUEuqlg
2. Chair of Technology, Ethics, and Society: https://t.co/Bib8p1ZoVT
3. Assistant Professor for Digital Ethics: https://t.co/eLUIO48NwZ
I'm the primary mentor of Microsoft Research's Sociotechnical Infrastructures internship: https://t.co/deR6PytWdE Deadline is tomorrow (1/11).
Reminder: Most Microsoft Research SMC internship applications due tomorrow (1/11). See all of them listed here: https://t.co/PXaVlW0y4I

I continue to be so inspired by friends whose devotion to justice and public good leads them into service. Thank you @amac! (Also, omg the combo of you + @AlondraNelson46 @SureshVenkat46 @kdphd @DeniceRoss46 and so many others... wowsers!)
@welkjoerger @muira_mccammon “Picking Up: On the Streets and Behind the Trucks with the Sanitation Workers of New York City” by Robin Nagle -> fabu ethnography + history
Is comms your thing? @datasociety is doing a cluster hire of different comms roles. Check them out! https://t.co/uQAaMVdxWb
Research Analyst opening @datasociety for a new program - Public Tech Leadership Collaborative. Check it out: https://t.co/MZFBUt9FJP
At the Microsoft Research Summit, I gave a talk on "Statistical Imaginaries: An Ode to Responsible Data Science." Read the text: https://t.co/iR8ETyjcHD Watch the video: https://t.co/NyoZ0o48O4

Academics: @datasociety is seeking two Faculty Fellows focused on Race, Tech, and the State. These are paid fellowships designed to support novel research. Deadline 12/15. See: https://t.co/Uw1l6ZllFd

Even when govt recognizes people need care, politicians often presume those seeking care are fraudulent. @cariatidaa at @datasociety just published crucial and insightful research about surveillance tech in carework: https://t.co/I02GzT8hYy

PhD students: Microsoft Research has opened its calls for internships. Interested? 1) Social Media Collective: https://t.co/PDNg7st9fK and 2) Sociotechnical infrastructures (w/ me): https://t.co/deR6PytWdE (app deadline 1/11)

Exciting news: I'm a visiting distinguished prof at @Georgetown this year to help kickstart their Center for Digital Ethics & work with amazing faculty/students on various research puzzles while writing a new book. https://t.co/UItjIvj3ju (Still at MSR too!)

A filmmaker made a mini-documentary about my grandfather's service during WWII. My grandpa will turn 100 next month. It's truly amazing to have this video gift. https://t.co/SUBVs1VssE Thank you @memoirs_of_wwii!

For all those who are seeking recent independent research on teens and social media, check out "The Unseen Teen" by @Amanda_Lenhart & @_kellie_owens_  Very relevant to the current convo: https://t.co/Tkpyjr1EyD

The @MSFTResearch Summit will take place Oct 19-21. Open to all! A wide mix of technical, scientific, & socsci talks. I have the honor of getting to present some of my new research, as well as hosting an interview with @john_abowd. Join us! https://t.co/AsalgAmwNw
Are you a student seeking a career in Public Interest Technology? Trying to find someone for such a role? Check out this career fair: https://t.co/sUxM78WqH3

Algorithmic Impact Assessments offer a framework for evaluating and governing algorithmic systems. Want to learn more? The @datasociety team just released a report and a policy brief detailing how this can be operationalized: https://t.co/otI5zGWAvr

Awww... While I was on vacay, all sorts of census stakeholders tweeted #CensusIsUs. It's such a good reminder that our democracy's data infrastructure is made of, by, and for the public interest. I continue to be in awe of all of those who work to make this data possible. https://t.co/1I6JFWMI6d

Three pieces of fabulous interlocking news about @datasociety's Director of Research: 1) current DoR @SareetaAmrute received a Sage fellowship (w00t); 2) @jennaburrell joins D&S in Sept 2021 (yippeee); 3) D&S is seeking a 2022-23 DoR (is that you??): https://t.co/ZPm3NoRvnp

"Come on, CDC, we need you" reflects the existential challenge that govt agencies that do science face right now. Data is nuanced, and messy. But many people don't treat data that way. So then what? https://t.co/ke3aw4nHUa https://t.co/lvH9ZcqJIX
New scholarship by @alicetiara on "morally motivated networked harassment" is super relevant for all who care about disinfo, platforms, hate, and harassment. Open-access: https://t.co/P5jSYfknFg

There's been a lot of confusion this week about how to interpret differentially privacy census data. This essay by privacy experts describes how to think about statistical inference and privacy:  https://t.co/79UzYrC1sQ https://t.co/SeZ7VqbYZA

PhD students: @datasociety is hiring a postdoc to work on "trustworthy infrastructures" to ask: "how is trust situated within [tech, social media] infrastructures and how can safe infrastructures be designed from the margins?" https://t.co/NzPmOUL3q2

How can YOU help remedy polarization and hate? You can help knit the social fabric of our society by strategically understanding networks and doing repairwork. Learn more from a talk I gave at #ELI2021. Script is here:
https://t.co/nayfL2aCR7

"The Constant Boss" by @aihanguyen examines how surveillance of low-wage/hourly workers continues to evolve, with both new technologies & the pandemic serving to speed up the harms/abuse. If you care about workers rights or privacy, this is important:  https://t.co/lFsZ80s7VW

New to the census/differential privacy convo? NPR's @hansilowang just posted a succinct intro/framing piece: https://t.co/wM34QxTgRo (I expect the weeds to take over the lawn on this one very shortly so brace yourself!)

One of my beloved collaborators @geomblog is simultaneously jumping to work with one of my favorite people @AlondraNelson46 at the White House AND going to my dear alma mater @BrownCSDept. I am verklempt with joy.

Upcoming speakers include: 
May 26: @SareetaAmrute 
June 30: @KimTallBear 
July 28: @cmcilwain 
Aug 18: @ruha9 
And beyond: @lnakamur @simonebrown @DocDre @KishonnaGray @DrDesmondPatton @denaefordrobin  and more!!

The @MSFTResearch "Race and Technology" lecture series is publicly accessible. It's filled with amazing speakers, starting with @datasociety's brilliant Director of Research @SareetaAmrute on May 26. Check out this lineup and join us! https://t.co/Jaw5UDgwjq

The @MSRNE Social Media Collective has an amazing group of incoming interns/postdocs. One of those interns - @muira_mccammon - will work directly with me to examine how government agencies speak. w00t! Check out these fantastic junior scholars:  https://t.co/6jB9FH4MOm

Care about youth mental health? @Amanda_Lenhart and @_kellie_owens_ just put out a @datasociety report on "the challenges of building healthy tech for young people" that dives into how design choices behind tech platforms harms youth: https://t.co/Tkpyjr1EyD

To transition people out of survival mode without a spike in suicide ideation post-pandemic will require building a holistic mental health strategy. I'm not at all convinced that we're prepared for that as a country. ::gulp::

Data from CTL & elsewhere are showing a lower level of suicidality this year. This is not reassuring in my mind. Combined with anxiety spikes and higher need, this suggests that people have gone into survival mode. Such a mode is good short term, but requires preparation...

Folks at @CrisisTextLine have just published a 50-state report on mental health in the US: https://t.co/yRRqniHlnS Most notably, this data reveal the degree to which people are struggling with anxiety.

On 4/30 at 5PM ET, I'm celebrating @Greene_DM's new book - "The Promise of Access" - by participating in a panel. The convo will inevitably challenge techno-idealism, invoking librarians, bootcamps, & Atari Democrats. Join us!  https://t.co/0fldvT8Ghy

Digital Barriers to Economic Justice, a @datasociety report by @profmgilman & @mary_madden examines interplay of surveillance, digital profiling, automation to reinforce inequality in light of the pandemic: https://t.co/UCS3zwlvPT

Tonite at 5PM ET, I'm participating in an @nyu_ipk panel on "Contact and Distance in the Post-Pandemic Social World" w/ @NatashaSchull @paul_dimaggio @merbroussard @EricKlinenberg || Join us, RSVP:   https://t.co/BNHFKE1wrG

Ever wonder why the US House has been stuck at 435 people for 100 years? Turns out that number got entangled with an algorithm. Or, rather, an algo was implemented to secure that number. "House Arrest" by @danbouk is fun, fascinating drama-filled history: https://t.co/iUMLxwJC8x
Call for Proposals: Actualizing AI regulation to build equity and trust. For @EPICprivacy Symposium on Regulating AI. Abstracts due 6/1. More deets: https://t.co/b7YTh0qPnk

This article was like reading a memory. The story of my 20s. Only articulated better. I still long for those days, that cafeteria, the all-encompassing experience. I know better but I’m still jealous of those who get to live in that fantasy land. https://t.co/sOFEzMZORQ
Grateful for an administration who recognizes the importance of privacy.
Trying to better understand disinformation studies? @alicetiara @rachelkuo @Sjonescameron  and @moiragweigel have put together a fabulous syllabus: https://t.co/mfEGo9PwHH

Until 1790, censuses were solely used by the State for abusive purposes - to conscript people, tax them, and directly harm them. (Censuses were conducted by censors.) People have been fighting since to use censuses to empower. Let's not backtrack on that.

Umm.. why would anyone think it's a good idea to merge the IRS and the census? President Taft argued: "The sole purpose of the Census is to secure general statistical information... The Census has nothing to do with taxation..."  https://t.co/VOG3dTPjjv https://t.co/sznzeLcFZs

This spring, I am committing to writing more. If you'd like to be notified of new writing, I've created a (free) newsletter: https://t.co/n7koHpVVHY Topics include: census, algo accountability, privacy, etc.

(But first, a vacation! I will be offline all of next week.)

Sometimes, technology spectacle obfuscates other political tensions. Starting with what happened when Congress didn't reapportion after the 1920 census @danbouk and I examine different moments in census history when a fight was seemingly about math: https://t.co/lwD2u2YYHP

Are you "pursuing creative and meaningful projects that examine, interpret, develop, or apply technology to shape a better future for humanity"? @ComputerHistory has prizes for global changemakers (due March 28): https://t.co/QORkG3hnix https://t.co/2bL6DpYaeG

"Science for Social Equity" is a @FairCount project by the inimitable @JAbramsMcLean to bring scientists and community organizers together to solve problems. Organizers & scientists: apply to be a (funded) fellow by March 20: https://t.co/9HCKPub78u https://t.co/EX4ACdD9P3

The @uscensusbureau Household Pulse Survey repeatedly reveals the ripples and pain wreaked from the pandemic. Take a moment to think about the people/stories behind these data: https://t.co/o4y1OIUOt2
Next Friday (Feb 19), I will be speaking in a session at the Computation + Journalism Symposium. If this topic tickles your brain, register here: https://t.co/TPx1DQb9iB
Apply to @datasociety workshop on "The Hustle Economy: Race, Gender, and Digital Entrepreneurship" by March 1: https://t.co/UnwyE5zA7m

Academics: @MSFTResearch has a dissertation grant program for "underrepresented" students in computing-related fields in US/Canada universities. If you know an eligible doctoral student, let them know! https://t.co/mhjfbisvNS

"Puppet Entrepreneurship" is a new @datasociety
 report by @brian_callaci that interrogates electronic monitoring in franchises, revealing broader patterns of surveillance in work. Wanna better understand the gig economy or worker surveillance? Read this! https://t.co/MoXrbcxxIX https://t.co/KtLh5t8eKw
I find it so calming to hear a politician recognize the professionalism of civil servants.
Who deserves the Patrick J McGovern Tech Humanity Prize? The @ComputerHistory Museum is accepting nominations: https://t.co/BvbOcwdsI3
This. Poem.  ::jaw on floor::
This is soooo delightfully geeky. {{hug}} to @mattcutts and all of @USDS. So much to build on this new day!
This weekend, in honor of MLK, many members of the public will engage in a National Day of Service. @CrisisTextLine has a variety of options for those seeking to volunteer: https://t.co/YPNVPQECs0

In the US, we have lost faith in science/data/expertise. We need to restore faith in knowledge-building, but not uncritically. We must integrate different ways of knowing while strengthening the development of knowledge. This is the cornerstone of STS. And why I heart @alondra.

I've long thought that the Office of Science/Tech/Policy needed more STS/social science minds inside. I literally cannot think of a better person than @alondra to serve as the incoming Deputy Director. I'm giddy thinking about how much good she can do. https://t.co/uTz2PplKwH

Speakers of languages that gender cats, cars, and cables: are discussions of gendered pronouns involving humans also invoking questions of gendering nouns more generally? How are different language communities debating gender right now?

Are you researching public-sector data infrastructures? Whether you have a paper to workshop or want to participate in workshopping others' papers, application deadline for @datasociety workshop is Friday! https://t.co/LccauLApiC
